title: Best Running Shoes for Bad Knees: Doctor Recommended
content:
Knee pain doesn't mean you have to stop running. The right shoes can reduce impact and keep you moving. Dr. Amanda Foster, orthopedic surgeon specializing in sports medicine, shares her recommendations.

"Cushioning is critical for runners with knee issues," Dr. Foster explains. "But stability matters too - poor alignment increases knee stress."

Our Top Picks

#1 Best Overall: Hoka Bondi 8
Maximum cushioning protects knees from impact. The Meta-Rocker design reduces stress on joints during transition. Dr. Foster calls it "the most protective option available."
Why it works: Thick foam absorbs shock before it reaches knees
Consider if: You want maximum protection
Price: $165

#2 Best for Stability: Brooks Adrenaline GTS 23
Knee pain often stems from alignment issues. The GuideRails system controls motion without restricting natural movement. DNA LOFT cushioning is gentle on joints.
Why it works: Addresses both cushioning and alignment
Consider if: You overpronate or have tracking issues
Price: $140

#3 Best Cushioning + Support: ASICS Gel-Kayano 30
GEL technology absorbs impact exceptionally well. The 4D Guidance System provides stability. A premium option for serious knee protection.
Why it works: Combines gel cushioning with motion control
Consider if: You need significant support
Price: $160

#4 Best Lightweight Option: Hoka Clifton 9
Not everyone wants heavy maximum cushion shoes. The Clifton provides substantial protection at only 7.2 oz. Rocker geometry eases knee stress.
Why it works: Protection without weight penalty
Consider if: You want cushioning without bulk
Price: $145

#5 Best Value: Saucony Triumph 21
PWRRUN+ foam rivals expensive competitors. Excellent cushioning at a reasonable price. Often on sale.
Why it works: Premium cushioning, better price
Consider if: Budget matters
Price: $160

Dr. Foster's Additional Advice

"Shoes help, but they're not the only solution. Strengthening exercises for quads and glutes reduce knee stress significantly. Consider physical therapy if pain persists."

She also recommends:
- Replace shoes every 300-400 miles
- Avoid running on concrete when possible
- Consider softer surfaces for recovery runs
- Don't increase mileage more than 10% weekly

When to Stop Running

Seek medical attention if you experience:
- Sharp, sudden knee pain
- Swelling that doesn't resolve
- Locking or catching sensations
- Pain that worsens despite rest

With proper shoes and smart training, many runners with knee issues continue running for decades.
